Award.AwardTitle: Threading Flavones Through The Undergraduate Chemistry Laboratory Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Chemistry (12) "Threading Flavones through the Undergraduate Chemistry Laboratory Curriculum" is a project led by the Georgia Institute of Technology in collaboration with a variety of other colleges and universities to develop a model for the integration of learning across the chemistry laboratory curriculum. A set of interconnected learning activities called "threads" are being developed and implemented in laboratory courses from the sophomore to senior levels. Flavones are the central class of molecules for this proof-of-concept study because students can learn about their chemical diversity, relevant synthesis, biological reactivity, and interesting chemical properties in appropriate laboratory courses throughout the curriculum. This project is testing the hypothesis that teaching undergraduate chemistry using "threads" will promote: (i) retention of key concepts throughout the curriculum, (ii) critical thinking, (iii) technical skills development, (iv) collaborative problem solving, and (v) appreciation of the relevancy of chemical concepts to human health. Incorporation of "threads" throughout the curriculum is placing the practice of science in a new perspective for many undergraduate students, allowing them to retain more content from previous classes and improving their overall engagement in the learning experience. Two of the major benefits of this project are the preparation of a database of educational resources, particularly for institutions that lack costly, major instrumental facilities such as mass spectrometers and NMRs, and three faculty development workshops to aid in the dissemination of this project to other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Threading Flavones” project in the School of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Georgia Tech is an educational model for interconnecting a scientific theme across upper division laboratory courses. In the Threading Flavones project, six experiments were adapted and implemented into three upper division laboratory courses: Synthesis Laboratory I (CHEM 2380, a sophomore-level organic synthesis course), Synthesis Laboratory II (CHEM 3380, a junior-level organic and inorganic synthesis course), and Biochemistry Laboratory II (CHEM 4582, a senior-level biochemistry course). Flavonoids that were synthesized by undergraduates in the sophomore and junior level courses were tested by students for their structure and chemical properties including mass, melting point, IR spectrum, and 1H NMR spectrum of the dry product. Student-synthesized flavonoids were then donated to seniors in Biochemistry Laboratory II for testing their biological activity. Specifically, students investigated the impact of commercial vs. student-synthesized flavonoids on the activity of a signal transduction enzyme called Protein Kinase C (PKC). (Elevated levels of PKC are indicators of cancer.) Students also docked structures of flavonoids into PKC using free software (AutoDock Vina) in order to hypothesize structure-function correlations. Finally, students conducted a ligand binding study to characterize the affinity of flavonoids to albumin, a blood transport protein for wide variety of small molecules.  

 

The application of AutoDock Vina into the Biochemistry laboratory curriculum led to an unexpected outcome with broader impact. The draft protocol was sent to a colleague (Dr. Stephen Harvey, Professor and Georgia Research Alliance Eminent Scholar in Structural Biology) for informal feedback on its technical merit. Professor Harvey then introduced PI Peek to a researcher at Emory University who happened to have inquired about wanting to collaborate with someone familiar with the software. After an ongoing collaboration for the next 16 months, a research article was published in “Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Infectious Diseases.” Although the paper was not directly related to the topic of flavonoid research, the collaboration would not have been possible had it not been for the activities associated with the Threading Flavones project.

 

A major outcome of the Threading Flavones project was the undergraduate research for experiment development, adaptation and implementation. Over the course of the project, 15 undergraduates worked as researchers for faculty who teach the laboratory courses and manage the teaching laboratories, gaining invaluable independent research and professional work experience.

 

The most impactful outcome of the Threading Flavones project was the hosting of two summer faculty development workshops in 2012 and 2014. The Summer 2012 workshop was held over two days and was attended by seven faculty from the following local institutions:

  • Kennesaw State University (Kennesaw, GA)
  • Samford University (Birmingham, AL)
  • Agnes Scott College (Decatur, GA) – a small liberal arts, women’s college
  • Georgia Perimeter College (Decatur, GA) –now merged with Georgia State University
  • Spelman College (Atlanta, GA) – a historically Black, women’s college
  • Georgia State University (Atlanta, GA)

 

Faculty members conducted the three biochemistry experiments in the Threading Flavones project and participated in group discussions about the content.

 

The Summer 2014 Threading Flavones workshop was held on July 21-23, 2014 and was attended by 32 faculty from community colleges, small liberal arts colleges and universities, and research institutions primarily throughout the Southeastern US. The following schools were represented:

  • Alabama A&M University (Huntsville, AL) – a historically Black university
  • Albany State University (Albany, GA) – a historically Black university
  • Brunswick Community College (Supply, NC)
  • Caldwell Community College (Hudson, NC)
  • Clemson University (Clemson, SC)
  • Davidson College (Davidson, NC)
  • Eastern Nazarene College (Quincy, MA)
  • Georgia Perimeter College – Dunwoody campus (Atlanta, GA) – now merged with Georgia State University
  • Georgia State University (Atlanta, GA)
  • Jacksonville State University (Jacksonville, AL)
  • Midlands Technical College (Columbia, SC)
  • Oakwood University (Huntsville, AL) – a historically Black university
  • Spelman College (Atlanta, GA) – a historically Black, women’s college
  • Talladega College (Talladega, AL) – a historically Black college
  • Tuskegee University (Tuskegee, AL) – a historically Black university
  • University of North Carolina at Pembroke (Pembroke, NC)
  • University of Texas at Arlington (Arlington, TX)
  • Volunteer State Community College (Gallatin, TN)
  • Wesleyan College (Macon, GA) – a small, liberal arts women’s college
  • Xavier University of Louisiana (New Orleans, LA) – a historically Black university
  • Young Harris College (Young Harris, GA)

 

In addition to the workshops, the Threading Flavones project was disseminated to the scientific community via poster presentations at the Experimental Biology 2012 conference, the 2013 American Chemical Society annual meeting, a Gordon Research conference on Chemical Education Research and Practice: Chemistry Education as an Agent in Global Progress in 2015, and the 2015 special symposium on Transforming Undergraduate Education in the Molecular Life Sciences.
